facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 356 and 357 of 1966 are appeals by special leave from the Award of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan in Case No. 9 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 356 and 357 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the Award of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan

facts.text: The award of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan is dated May 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: against the award dated May 4, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan to which reference was made under section 10 1  d  of the Industrial Dispu

facts.text: Reference to the Tribunal was made under section 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: against the award dated May 4, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan to which reference was made under section 10 1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: The dispute referred relates to the workmen's demand for bonus for the years 1956-57 to 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute referred to the Tribunal related to the workmens demand for bonus for the years 1956-57 to 1959-60.

facts.text: The Tribunal disallowed the claim for bonus for 1956-57 on the ground that it was belated.

anchor.surface_text: By the said award the Tribunal disallowed the claim for 1956-57 on the ground that it was belated and allowed the demand for the rest of the years 1957-58 to 1959-60.

facts.text: The Tribunal allowed the demand for bonus for 1957-58 to 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: By the said award the Tribunal disallowed the claim for 1956-57 on the ground that it was belated and allowed the demand for the rest of the years 1957-58 to 1959-60.

facts.text: Gross profits for 1957-58 were Rs. 28.29 lacs.

facts.text: There is no dispute about the gross profits figures.

facts.text: No dispute with regard to figures for depreciation, income-tax and wealth tax.

facts.text: For 1959-60, Company claimed interest at 8.57% on paid-up capital due to change in Income-tax law.

anchor.surface_text: For 1959-60 the Company remanded interest at the rate of 8.57 by reason of a change in he Income-tax law having been made during the year.

facts.text: Union claimed 6% interest on paid-up capital for 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The Union, on the other hand, claimed that only 6 interest should be allowed.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed 7 1/4% interest on paid-up capital for 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal allowed a mean between the two, viz., 7 1/4.

facts.text: Main dispute in appeals is regarding rehabilitation allowances for plant and machinery for three years and method of calculation.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case the Tribunal estimated the life for old machinery at 10 years and that for new machinery at 15 years after taking into companysideration

facts.text: Entire machinery needed immediate replacement, accepted by Tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Tribunal erred in calculating replacement cost for old machinery, should have used quotations leading to Rs. 121.70 lacs instead of Rs. 85.62 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: The replacement companyt thus arrived at would be Rs. 121.70 lacs as against Rs. 85.62 lacs as worked by the Tribunal.

facts.text: After modifications, available surplus is Nil for 1957-58, 1958-59, 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The, Chartst showing calculations of available surplus for the A three bonus years show that in all these years numbersurplus remains available for distribution

facts.text: Supreme Court allows Company's appeal and sets aside Tribunal's direction for payment of bonus for three years.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, the appeal by the Company must be allowed and the direction made by the Tribunal for payment of bonus for these three years has to be set aside.

facts.text: Workmen's appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of this case, the parties will bear their own companyts. The appeal by the Union is dismissed.

facts.text: Bonus claim for 1956-57 raised first on July 24, 1959, more than 18 months after accounts closed.

anchor.surface_text: The claim for bonus was raised for the first time by the Unions resolution of July 24, 1959, that is, more than 18 months after the closure of accounts.

facts.text: Company's fixed assets valued at about Rs. 110 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: As found by the Tribunal the Companys fixed assets were of the value of about Rs. 110 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal followed Full Bench formula from Millowners Association case approved in Associated Cement Co. case.

anchor.surface_text: In working out the available surplus for distribution as bonus the Tribunal in general followed the Full Bench formula evolved by the Labour Appellate Tribunal

facts.text: No question of interest on working capital as no reserve utilised as working capital.

facts.text: No dispute regarding rehabilitation charge for buildings.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was right in disallowing the claim for bonus for 1956-57 on the ground that it was belated.

anchor.surface_text: By the said award the Tribunal disallowed the claim for 1956-57 on the ground that it was belated and allowed the demand for the rest of the years 1957-58 to 1959-60.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim raised more than 18 months after closure of accounts; bonus not deferred wages; laches fatal as per series of decisions.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in not accepting quotations as replacement cost for old machinery instead of notional multipliers; replacement cost is Rs. 121.70 lacs not Rs. 85.62 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal ought to have accepted those quotations as equivalent to replacement cost as it did in the case of new machinery instead of adopting the notional method

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quotations undisputed best evidence of probable replacement cost; more accurate than hypothetical multipliers per Associated Cement; leads to higher rehab cost wiping out surplus.

holdings.text: Quotations can be sole criterion for rehabilitation cost where undisputed and itemwise feasible.

anchor.surface_text: The question still is whether the quotations can be the sole criterion for working out rehabilitation cost.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Itemwise from quotations preferable to blockwise/multipliers when possible per Associated Cement; here undisputed, project future price level.

holdings.text: Burden of proof is on employer to show claimed replacement costs do not include expansion.

anchor.surface_text: The question is on whom is the burden of proving whether a given replacement amounts to.expansion,or modernization.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Employer seeks deduction as prior charge; must satisfy Tribunal via evidence; discharged here by statements, witnesses, annexures unchallenged.

holdings.text: Rs. 48.83 lacs depreciation reserve is deductible from rehabilitation cost for 1950-51 machinery.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company next objected to the sum of Rs. 48.83 lacs having been deducted from rehabilitation cost in respect of machinery, old and new,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depreciation fund available for earliest rehab need regardless of item; company admitted deduction in Ex. M-4; no principle restricts to specific item.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in deducting Rs. 30 lacs depreciation twice over for old machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thus deducted Rs. 30 lacs as depreciation twice over. The deduction of Rs. 30 lacs was thus clearly an error.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deducted as old machinery cost to seller and again in total depreciation reserve; clear miscalculation.

holdings.text: Rs. 18.22 lacs investment in shares is available for deduction from rehabilitation cost.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Liquid assets convertible to cash; prima facie extra capital; company did not dispute before Tribunal.

holdings.text: Average life of new machinery is 15 years, not 25 years.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No rigidity; depends on industry/evidence; precision machinery on 3 shifts justifies 15 years.

holdings.text: Notional normal depreciation, not statutory depreciation including development rebate, deductible for rehabilitation requirement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Full Bench formula and Associated Cement chart; statutory used only for income-tax.

holdings.text: 6% interest on paid-up capital is not inflexible; adjustable to balance industry/labour claims.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable return on investment; Tribunal discretion if lower than 6% after facts; per Associated Cement.

holdings.text: Tribunal's uniform remainder life divisor of 7 years for old machinery incorrect; graduated divisor based on installation year required.

anchor.surface_text: As stated earlier, the Tribunal has given in Annex. A a uniform remainder life of 7 years to old machinery irrespective of the year of its installation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Life 10 years; remainder varies by installation year (e.g., 1950-51: 3 years in 1957-58).

holdings.text: No available surplus for bonus after correct rehabilitation; Tribunal's direction for bonus payment set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The, Chartst showing calculations of available surplus for the A three bonus years show that in all these years numbersurplus remains available for distribution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrected rehab costs (using quotations, no double dep, etc.) wipe out surplus per Full Bench formula.

holdings.text: Quotations include spares cost, properly included.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Common for imported precision machinery to avoid delays.

holdings.text: No rehabilitation claimed for discarded machinery worth Rs.18 lacs as adjusted in fixed assets/depreciation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Removed from fixed assets ledger; depreciation deducted; no claim made.

holdings.text: No rule limiting old machinery rehabilitation to 30%; full cost where proved.
holdings.reasoning_summary: South India ad-hoc due to lack of evidence; full where purchase price/depreciation ascertained.
